author: By Ana Swanson
title: “Following NAFTA’s adoption, our nation lost one in four manufacturing jobs.”
description: The United States has lost about four million of its 17 million factory jobs since NAFTA went into effect in 1994. But American factory employment actually increased in the years immediately after the deal going into effect, and few economists blame the North American trade deal for the kind of immense job loss the president is talking about. Economists debate the jobs effects from NAFTA, but most agree that the deal had a relatively modest impact, destroying jobs in some communities where factories went to Mexico, but creating other jobs elsewhere. China’s entry into the global trading system when it joined the World Trade Organization in 2001, as well as continued automation in factories, has led to more significant job losses in the manufacturing sector.

description: Officers’ most-used item since the 1800s isn’t the gun or handcuffs, but the handwritten activity log. Now an iPhone app is replacing it.
content: For more than a century, the New York City Police Department has required its officers to keep a detailed, handwritten memo book while on patrol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose
title: Epoch Times, Punished by Facebook, Gets a New Megaphone on YouTube
description: The paper, started by practitioners of Falun Gong, has turned to the video platform for an advertising blitz.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Late last summer, YouTube users began noticing a surge of ads for an obscure news outlet called The Epoch Times. One ad touted an exposé of “Spygate,” a baseless conspiracy theory alleging that President Barack Obama and his allies placed a spy inside President Trump’s 2016 campaign. Another praised Mr. Trump’s interest in buying Greenland as a shrewd strategic move. A third claimed that the opioid epidemic in the United States was the result of a chemical warfare plot by the Chinese Communist Party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Julian E. Barnes
title: NATO Eyes Troop Reductions in Afghanistan as U.S. Draws Down
description: The Trump administration’s decision to eventually withdraw several thousand troops from America’s longest war has triggered a debate within the 29-country alliance.
content: WASHINGTON — Some members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization are considering withdrawing thousands of their forces from Afghanistan once the United States begins to officially cut its own presence in the country, according to American and European officials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Phillips
title: Stocks Shrug Off Outbreak Worries and Reach New Record
description: Solid economic reports and corporate earnings bolstered equity and commodity markets.
content: A third straight day of gains on Wall Street on Wednesday raised stocks to a record, as investors took comfort in signs that the American economy was on solid footing despite risks tied to the spread of the coronavirus both inside and outside China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: With Mookie Betts Trade, Red Sox Stick to an Unpopular Plan
description: Less than 16 months removed from a World Series title, Boston dealt its best player, to the displeasure of many fans. Now the club must weather the storm and rebuild — quickly.
content: After 12 championship parades over the last two decades, Boston is suddenly reeling. Days after a Super Bowl was somehow staged without the New England Patriots playing in it, and with quarterback Tom Brady, the face of their franchise, in limbo, the city received news that was widely anticipated — yet still felt like a kick in the pants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan and Julie Bosman
title: Hundreds of Americans Were Evacuated From the Coronavirus Epicenter. Now Comes the Wait.
description: About 350 Americans arrived Wednesday on government-arranged flights from China. They will be quarantined at military bases for 14 days.
content: LOS ANGELES — Americans evacuated from Hubei province in China arrived in California on government-arranged planes on Wednesday morning, and were greeted with applause by waiting medical personnel. They received health screenings, were warned to stay six feet away from the other families and were asked not to let children share toys.

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Johnson and BBC Trade Jabs, as War on the Press Flares
description: The British government is questioning the BBC’s public funding and even picking fights with papers that have backed Prime Minister Boris Johnson with gusto.
content: LONDON — When Prime Minister Boris Johnson delivered a fireside chat last week to mark Britain’s departure from the European Union, he did not ask the BBC to tape it, preferring to use an in-house video crew. The BBC, in turn, refused to air his remarks on that history-making evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Storming the Catwalk in an L.L. Bean Boot
description: After more than a century in business, the Maine heritage label makes its debut on a catwalk via the most modern of trends: the collab.
content: It was the impregnable fortress of heritage labels. Behind its clapboard walls lay an unlikely grail. Let international designers like Junya Watanabe and Demna Gvasalia have their way with Red Wing, Filson and North Face. Nobody touches L.L. Bean.

title: Impeachment Trial Updates: Senate Acquits Trump, Ending Historic Trial
description: President Trump was cleared of both impeachment charges. Only Mitt Romney crossed party lines, the lone Republican who voted to convict and remove the president from office.
content: The Senate acquitted President Trump on Wednesday of charges that he abused his power and obstructed Congress, as Republicans turned back an election-year attempt by House Democrats to remove him from office for pressuring a foreign power to incriminate his political rivals.
